discourse_list.title: Discussion: Use MKR as collateral instead of USDC to restore the peg in PSM-like designs

content.content: The peg is broken.   The PSM and several simplified variations of it that use a special USDC collateral type have been proposed that would enable us to mint Dai, sell the Dai and profit from the high Dai price, and help to restore the peg. One of the main sources of resistance to these designs is people’s reluctance to take on potentially hundreds of millions of USDC in collateral that could create great negative publicity as well as systemic risk for the protocol. Let’s consider the potential to use MKR as a collateral type to perform the same function as in the USDC schemes.  We would allocate say 50,000 MKR (~$25m) to a special vault that would be used to mint Dai, sell Dai to buy more MKR on the open market, and then repeat up to a specified LR. The main advantages of this approach is that it uses existing smart contracts, we avoid the negative publicity and centralization of USDC collateral.  Furthermore, it could provide much needed support for the current low MKR price. The only risk is the potential for liquidation in the case MKR price falls.  However, we have ways that we could handle such a scenario.  My preferred way is to turn off liquidations while Dai is above the peg and have unbacked dai.  Everyone buying Dai today at $1.03 is buying unbacked dai (as it is only backed by $1 of collateral) and yet demand for it is very strong.  Allowing a controlled amount of unbacked Dai (up to vault debt ceiling) should help restore the peg.  Once the peg is restored and we are able to generate stability fee income again, rather than burning MKR with the SF income, we would buy MKR to make the MKR CDP whole again and then we would unwind the CDP and burn the 50,000 MKR collateral used to create it. I think the risks of this plan are lower than the negative publicity of taking on massive amounts of USDC collateral in PSM like schemes.  Furthermore, it would allow MKR holders to benefit directly from the massive demand for Dai that currently exists but is providing no benefit to them.

content.content: MKR crashes when it is undercollateralized because it has to issue MKR to cover the gap. If MKR backed DAI instead of independent assets, more MKR would have to be minted than otherwise. So MKR should never be collateral in makerdao.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: The CDP described above cannot lead to new MKR being issued.   MKR is minted to cover liquidated CDPs that cannot pay off their debts at auction.  In the proposal above, we would create a special MKR vault that was only usable by the protocol and liquidations would be turned off.  If the CDP became undercollateralized and Dai is above the peg, we would have unbacked dai.  If Dai is below the peg, we would buy MKR with the SF income to restore the CDP.  So- this cannot lead to MKR being minted. In fact, it is used to buy MKR on the open market from minted Dai to restore the peg.

content.content: Every new flashy feature that has to be built for some specific short term purpose takes away resources and focus from collateral onboarding, which is the simplest and only real solution for the long run. In trying to solve the problem it would make it worse.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Collateral onboarding really hasn’t helped at this point.  Also- this is not a flashy new feature,  I’m just arguing for using MKR as collateral in CDPs rather than USDC to restore the peg.  In both cases, we could set the LR at 101 and disable liquidations.   Using USDC avoids unbacked Dai but creates centralization risk.  Using MKR would create unbacked dai but avoid the risks of massive influx of centralized stable coins.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: I have advocated some kind of governance only accessible MKR vault for such operations but believe we have other better tools that we can persue. Inherently doing something like this multiples MKR pricing risk.
